emoreno2292

Many say that children who are raised by homosexual parents will not be raised as well as those by straight parents, or that kids who have homosexual parents are at a disadvantage. What are your thoughts?

post_info.post_title: Are kids of gay parents at a disadvantage?

Jaxian

My opinion likely goes without saying, but that's never stopped me from saying it in the past.
 
 Not only is there no rational justification for the assumption that same-sex parents would somehow be worse than opposite-sex parents, every reputable study on the subject has shown that same-sex parents are either just as good or better at raising children.
 
 The idea that same-sex parents are somehow worse than opposite-sex parents likely originated out of prejudice or the desire to believe that a child's biological parents are better able to raise that child because of some unspoken reason.
Jo Bennett

I would suggest that any averages in this sort of situation are completely meaningless. A good parent (or parents) is a good parent regardless of sex, sexual orientation or whatever else. There are bad heterosexual parents and bad homosexual parents.
joebrummer

I woudl suggest you ask the kids themselves.....
 
 www.colage.org
 
 in case I spelled it wrong which I am known to do. It stands for children of lesbian and gays everywhere....
gamehuis

This recently came up in another thread. Here's a cut and paste from my reply inthat thread:
 
 The American Psychological Association, representing more than 155,000 psychologists, states that children of gay and lesbian parents are at no disadvantage psychologically or socially compared to children of heterosexual parents.
 
 The American Academy of Pediatrics, the nation's leading pediatric authority with 57,000 members, says that children who grow up with gay and/or lesbian parents fare as well in emotional, cognitive, social and sexual functioning as children with straight parents.
 
 The National Association of Social Workers, with nearly 150,000 members, agrees that research on gay and lesbian parenting shows a total absence of pathological findings in their children.
 
 "Not a single study has found children of gay or lesbian parents to be disadvantaged in any significant respect relative to children of heterosexual parents. Indeed, the evidence to date suggests that home environments provided by gay and lesbian parents are as likely as those provided by heterosexual parents to support and enable children's psychosocial growth." -- Charles J. Patterson, researcher at the University of Virginia, 2004
 
 
 And there was a study in Norway that showed that children raised by lesbian couples aren't disadvantaged (Halvorsen and Joner, 2001).
 
 
 So no, the kids are by no means disadvantaged.

Vanguard

Well, that may be your opinion, but most science out there says something else......so your opinion on this is about the same as you saying the earth is flat.

 
 Not necessarily. First of all the studies performed on the subject are often highly politicized one way or another. A lot of the time they set out to prove their argument rather than to learn whether or not something is true.
 
 At any rate studies have also been performed showing the importance of having mothers in the home as well as having fathers in the home (no, I don't necessarily mean biological mothers and fathers, and yes, these too have a tendency to be politicized).
 
 I could state moral/religious reasons, but I'm pretty sure that won't matter to you, so I'm not going to bother.
 
 I submit that the differences between the sexes are there (whether designed by God or by evolution) so that males and females compliment each other in survival and reproduction. Thus a male and a female parent will best be able to raise children.
 
 Lastly, a male and a female parent provide role models for what a healthy heterosexual relationship should be like (and this is important since the overwhelming majority of people, for whatever reason you may think, are heterosexual).
Obvious Child

Not necessarily. First of all the studies performed on the subject are often highly politicized one way or another. A lot of the time they set out to prove their argument rather than to learn whether or not something is true.
 
 At any rate studies have also been performed showing the importance of having mothers in the home as well as having fathers in the home (no, I don't necessarily mean biological mothers and fathers, and yes, these too have a tendency to be politicized).
The importance of having a mother and a father in the home are likely to be based on comparisons to single parent families. And there can be female role models outside of your parents
 
 
I could state moral/religious reasons, but I'm pretty sure that won't matter to you, so I'm not going to bother.
So the kids would be morally and religiously disadvantaged? More likely to be evil and go to hell? That kinda thing?
 
 
I submit that the differences between the sexes are there (whether designed by God or by evolution) so that males and females compliment each other in survival and reproduction. Thus a male and a female parent will best be able to raise children.
How is a gay couple less likely to survive now that we are not hunter-gatherers? And obviously they'd adopt or use IVF, so reproduction is unimportant.
 
 
Lastly, a male and a female parent provide role models for what a healthy heterosexual relationship should be like (and this is important since the overwhelming majority of people, for whatever reason you may think, are heterosexual).
Assuming they have a healthy relationship. Not to mention the fact that many psychologists see such an upbringing as bringing it's own neuroses: maybe a straight son of gay parents would lack the Oedipus complex and be a healthier human being. Maybe he'd just dress better and get on better with girls: but without concrete evidence we can't assume he'd suffer.

 Yes, but like you pointed out (or maybe it was someone else--I don't quite remember), we can't really rely on studies anymore for this sort of thing because studies have become so political and agenda-driven regarding the topic of homosexuality in the last decade or two. Nevertheless, I can't really think of any good reason to prevent gay people from adopting. We have to remember that in many cases, the alternative is a life on the street for the kid, or in foster homes his whole childhood. Even with the understanding I have of homosexual relations being immoral, no parent is perfect and adoption is a separate issue here. If a person will give a kid love and caring support, I don't care if they are gay or what. It's better than what the kid would have otherwise.

If we tried to not strive for the best in parenting on the basis that not everyone does it right or the fact there are bad parents out there, we'd all be in pretty sad shape.  Your point is somewhat moot, since you can't know if a kid is gay or straight until past the point where most adoptions happen. Be that as it may, what do you base your conclusions on? If the parents love each other, and love the kid, then what does the sexuality of any of them matter? The only difference between gay love and straight love is the gender of those involved, which is to say no real difference at all. Having parents that love and respect each other is key, that's what you want the kid to pick up on. Their sexuality is irrelevant as far as I can see. What makes you think otherwise?

Tony,
 
There is nothing to base those assumptions on, however. 

 
 Nothing besides reasoning and logic, no.
 
 

 And what do you say to those loving heterosexual parents who has a child who acts out in destructive behavior because of harassment that child receives in school for reasons OTHER than homosexuality?

 
 I'm not sure of the thrust of your question here. Are you saying that a child confused about his sexual identity would never act out because of that confusion? And are you saying that this child raised in an environment where homosexuality was 'normal' would not have any benefit from that environment?
 
 You would be a fool to argue that the environment where a child is raised has no impact upon that child. A home with a gay couple raising a child would show that child how to act in a loving homosexual relationship. However, men and women are different, and behave differently in relationships. In a relationship between a man and a woman, the dynamic will be different than a relationship between a man and a man, or a woman and a woman. An adolescent boy who is discovering that he is gay will have the touchstone for behavior in a relationship be those who he looks up to, who ideally will be his parents. If his parents are in a heterosexual relationship, the boy will not have had the benefit of knowing the dynamic in a homosexual relationship. Is this irreparable? No. Would there be a benefit if he was exposed to this dynamic? Yes.
 
 Kronus,
 

 Your point is somewhat moot, since you can't know if a kid is gay or straight until past the point where most adoptions happen. Be that as it may, what do you base your conclusions on? If the parents love each other, and love the kid, then what does the sexuality of any of them matter? The only difference between gay love and straight love is the gender of those involved, which is to say no real difference at all. Having parents that love and respect each other is key, that's what you want the kid to pick up on. Their sexuality is irrelevant as far as I can see. What makes you think otherwise?

 
 Yes, we are speaking of purely hypothetical situations since, as you say, we cannot know the orientation of the child in question.
 
 I base my conclusions on reasoning and logic, and if you disagree with a premise of mine, show me how I would be wrong. The sexuality matters because that determines the genders this hypothetical child would be exposed to in the home, as you yourself pointed out. Contrary to what you may think, men and women are different and behave differently in relationships. Whether or not you think these differences are significant is another subject. A heterosexual (or "destined to be heterosexual" if you prefer), child growing up in a home with homosexual parents would not be able to observe the dynamic between a man and a woman in a loving relationship. Yes, this child may be able to observe this outside the home (and any parent worth their salt expose their kids to other viewpoints) but having role-models in the home in the form of the child's parents would be preferable than outside, imo.
 
 In addition to this, I believe you would be a fool to argue that the biological connection of birth parents has zero influence upon both the parents and the child. Shared traits, be they personality or physical, can provide a bond that otherwise would not exist were this child adopted. For these reasons, I believe a child, generally speaking and all else being equal, has the most ideal situation being raised by its birth parents (both of them). Not only can they provide both gender viewpoints (so even a homosexual child of either gender has someone to identify with even if not sexually), but has a biological bond as well.
 
 For an adoptive child, a loving home is the best thing that can happen to him or her, regardless of the sexuality of the couple (and I do believe a couple is preferable to a single parent home).
Kronus

Contrary to what you may think, men and women are different and behave differently in relationships. Whether or not you think these differences are significant is another subject. A heterosexual (or "destined to be heterosexual" if you prefer), child growing up in a home with homosexual parents would not be able to observe the dynamic between a man and a woman in a loving relationship. 

 
 This is where you lose me. Your statement that men and women behave differently has an underlying assumption that men act in one consistant fasion and women in another. I don't think this is true; it certainly hasn't been my experience. There may be some general trends, but I know of no behavior that's specific to one gender. Likewise, the relationship you see between one man and woman is likely to be completely different than between a different man and woman, even if both relationships are good and loving. But you could find a similar dynamic between two men or two women as you see between a man and a woman. Bascially, people exhibit a wide, wide range of behaviors and relationships, and these differences, while influenced by gender, are not dictated by it. If you're going to claim that there's something special in a het dynamic that you won't find in a gay one, you're going to need to specify what it is, because I'm not convinced that such a thing exists.

Sigma

This is where you lose me. Your statement that men and women behave differently has an underlying assumption that men act in one consistant fasion and women in another. I don't think this is true; it certainly hasn't been my experience. There may be some general trends, but I know of no behavior that's specific to one gender.

 
 And what are these general trends? I'm afraid your experience must be limited, a situation predominated by one gender would be considerably different than an environment predominated by the other because men and women interact with each other in different ways.
 
 

 Likewise, the relationship you see between one man and woman is likely to be completely different than between a different man and woman, even if both relationships are good and loving. But you could find a similar dynamic between two men or two women as you see between a man and a woman. Bascially, people exhibit a wide, wide range of behaviors and relationships, and these differences, while influenced by gender, are not dictated by it.

 
 Behavior in relationships is, at least in part, learned by watching the dynamic of those in relationships around you. Men and women think differently, communicate differently and behave differently. Men act towards other men differently than they behave towards women, and women act differently towards women than they do towards men, and children learn this behavior. Children who are of a different sexual orientation will not have the touchstone on relationship behavior (what I call the "dynamic") that a child of the same sexual orientation would. I believe it is foolish in the extreme to argue there could be no benefit from growing up with and learning the dynamic of a heterosexual couple for a heterosexual child and a homosexual couple for a homosexual child (replace "child" with "teen discovering his or her sexuality" if you prefer)
 
 

 If you're going to claim that there's something special in a het dynamic that you won't find in a gay one, you're going to need to specify what it is, because I'm not convinced that such a thing exists.

 
 There is for a heterosexual child. There even is for a homosexual child, because there would still be a biological bond that would not be there with an adoptive couple, as well as providing both gender perspectives. Take for example a lesbian girl raised by two men. There would be no-one to model her behavior after within her immediate family unit and would have to look outside. At least with a heterosexual couple the lesbian girl would have a mother to identify with. I would not underestimate or denigrate this sort of relationship, were I you.

 You keep saying that there's a difference, but what I'd really like is for you to give specific examples. It seems to me what you're talking about, and I could be wrong, are stereotypical gender roles. Women cry, men don't. Women hug each other, men don't. Men belch, women don't. Etc. If this is what you're talking about then I will concede that these are learned behaviors, and parents are one source that kids would learn these behaviors from. However, I don't see these as things that we really want to pass on to kids. These stereotypes, while real to some degree, are not inherent to gender, but instead taught by society. Women are taught that they're supposed to be demure and emotional, men tough and rugged. I see no value in these roles, and so failure to pass these on to one's kids seems to me to be a good thing.
 
 Of course, I may be completely off base about what you actually meant. If so then please give specific examples of the different behaviors you were talking about.

Society is a benefit, yes, and we should work towards that. Nothing can replace your parents as role-models, though, nor should anything replace them (all else being equal).

 
 That would be nice, but that is not always case. What I am saying, though, is that the make up of the family doesn't necessarily determine who well adjusted a child will be in regards to anything. As long as a family is a part of society, there will will be too many other variables to take into consideration. To say that heterosexual children should be raised in a heterosexual household or gay children should be raised a gay household completely ignores all other factors/issues in raising a child.
Sigma

That would be nice, but that is not always case. What I am saying, though, is that the make up of the family doesn't necessarily determine who well adjusted a child will be in regards to anything.  Yes, I am ignoring all other factors/issues in raising a child because as you say there are too many variables with that to make any sort of determination. That is the reason, imo, studies are useless in determining this point. They cannot control for them all.
 
 I am saying, based on reason and logic, a heterosexual child in a home with his or her biological heterosexual parents has an advantage he or she would not have in a homosexual environment. I also believe a homosexual child (or "destined to be homosexual" if you prefer) would have an advantage being raised by homosexual parents of the same gender as the child. A heterosexual couple has many advantages and the only disadvantage is that they cannot show a growing child the dynamic of two loving people of the same gender.

 Because I am not a study, and I am making absolutely no judgement on what happens or does not happen outside the home. I am speaking soley on what would give the child an advantage inside the home. Your point is like saying: "It doesn't matter if the parents beat them because you are ignoring what good stuff can happen outside the home". It doesn't matter what is happening outside the home, we are dealing soley with what is happening inside.
 
 

 And I do not see that as logical conclusion, because you cannot ignore all the variables involved.

 
 Then you do not understand my point if that is your objection.
jyoshu

That would be nice, but that is not always case. What I am saying, though, is that the make up of the family doesn't necessarily determine who well adjusted a child will be in regards to anything. As long as a family is a part of society, there will will be too many other variables to take into consideration. To say that heterosexual children should be raised in a heterosexual household or gay children should be raised a gay household completely ignores all other factors/issues in raising a child.

 
 I think a lot of it depends on the family. If a family purposes to stay close despite society, then I think the parents will indeed be the main role model. It seems to me that a well-loved child in a family that's close has a better chance of being "well-adjusted" than one left to the whims and influences of society.

Does one spouse cheat on the other? Are they totally loving? Liberal or no? Monitor TV time or no? Babysitter come by on occasion? Allow sleepovers with other kids? What neighborhood do they live in? What kind a church (if church at all)?

Also, what makes you think that girls don't talk to each other in school?

Do you think that gay male couples wouldn't have female friends that they can rely on? Or better yet, in-laws? Sisters or mothers or garandmothers even? Google? A pediatrician? Families do not live in a vacuum.

 
 Well, you've moved from what parents can do for their children (versus society) to bringing in outside people. Do you think a daughter would be as comfortable talking to someone about this that she doesn't see that much or doesn't know as well, as she would a constantly-caring mother?

Are you seriously suggesting that a woman does not act differently towards a woman as towards a man in the same situation? I don't believe I need a specific example, my point is based soley on genders behaving towards one gender differently than the other without learned behavior. If you do not believe this, then I cannot debate you.

 
 What I'm suggesting is that when two people love each other, you'll see similar behaviors, regardless of gender, yes. They'll kiss and hug and hold hands, they'll call each other pet names, they'll do little things to make the other happy. You may not think you need to give a specific example, but it would really help me out here if you would anyway. What behavior, exactly, will a het couple exhibit that a gay couple won't that a het child needs to see. And please, be specific. "How men and women interact" tells me nothing. What, specifically, is so different about how hets interact compared to gays that is so important for a child to learn?
Sigma

What I'm suggesting is that when two people love each other, you'll see similar behaviors, regardless of gender, yes. They'll kiss and hug and hold hands, they'll call each other pet names, they'll do little things to make the other happy.

 
 I am not specifically talking about what all loving couples do, I am talking about how genders interact with each other. Let me ask you something, do you believe that a man and a woman, raised identically without "gender stereotypes", would have identical responses and reactions to every or nearly every situation or do you believe men and women tend to view and think about situations differently from one another?
 
 The examples you gave will suffice, but single examples are too specific for how broadly I'm talking about.
Sigma

And just because I don't accept it, it doesn't mean that I am ignoring it. I just don't agree with it.

 
 So be it. I have laid out my reasoning.

 We have no way of knowing, of course, but I tend to think that if raised identically, the behavoral differences between a man and a woman would be insignificant, if there were any at all.
 
 

 The examples you gave will suffice, but single examples are too specific for how broadly I'm talking about.

 The problem is that you're talking so broadly that I have no idea what you're trying to establish, beyond the fact that you don't think gays will make good parents. This seems like a really simple request to me; what, specifically, is so different about how hets interact compared to gays that is so important for a child to learn? If you can't answer it, can you at least go into some detail about why you can't? It seems to me that you're just asserting that there is a problem, without saying what the problem is.

 There are plenty of female role models a girl can turn to about this. Plus it's not that complicated - pick your feminine hygeine product and move on.

 
 Well, you're certainly more qualified to comment on it than I am (being that you're female and I'm male), but I suspect different adolescent girls handle this in different ways. IOW, I doubt it's a stretch to say that not every girl handles it as easily as you did. (yes, I do have a vested interest in this, as I have a daughter who will someday have to deal with this. But right on topic with the thread, while I will gladly give support to her in any way for ANY issue, I'm quite glad her mother can be there for her if she does need an ear of someone who's 'been there.')

Sigma

We have no way of knowing, of course, but I tend to think that if raised identically, the behavoral differences between a man and a woman would be insignificant, if there were any at all.

 
 Then there is no common ground between us on this issue, and there is no point to debate this further.
 
 

 The problem is that you're talking so broadly that I have no idea what you're trying to establish, beyond the fact that you don't think gays will make good parents. This seems like a really simple request to me; what, specifically, is so different about how hets interact compared to gays that is so important for a child to learn? If you can't answer it, can you at least go into some detail about why you can't? It seems to me that you're just asserting that there is a problem, without saying what the problem is.

 
 I have never said, thought, or intimated that gay parents would be bad parents. I am trying to establish that men and women approach problems and situations differently and think differently and react differently. When interacting with each other, a man and a woman couple would behave and react differently to situations that arise than a man and a man would or a woman and a woman would because men and women approach problems differently.
 
 A child growing up in an environment with a man and a woman will learn what a healthy heterosexual relationship is "supposed to" (at least what works) be like, and a child growing up in an environment with a gay couple (either gender) will learn what a healthy homosexual relationship is "supposed to" (at least what works) be like. The child will see how each of his or her parents approaches and reacts to the problem, will see how the other parent reacts to the first parents reaction, how arguments are resolved and what compromises work. In short, the dynamic of the couple and how the genders interact. And, since men and women react to situations differently, how this interaction happens will be different between heterosexual and homosexual couples.
 
 Since my premise is that men and women approach and react to situations differently, a heterosexual child in a heterosexual home will learn how a healthy heterosexual couple approaches problems and arrives at solutions while a homosexual child in a homosexual home will learn how a healthy homosexual couple approaches problems and arrives at solutions. However, this is all based upon the premise that men and women think about and approach problems differently. 
 
 Thus, my conclusion is that a heterosexual child has an advantage being raised in a heterosexual home rather than a homosexual home. A homosexual child has an advantage in a homosexual home only if the home he is being raised in is of the same gender as the child. A homosexual child still has an advantage in a heterosexual home because that child will still have a parent of the same gender to identify with and model at least some behavior after. I furthermore believe having a role-model in the home in the form of parents is preferable to having a role-model outside the home, even a family friend.
 
 However, since we do not agree that the genders approach or think about problems differently, there is no common ground to work from.
sinjin

Yes, I know a male role model could come from a family friend or a relative of the women. I don't see that as a certainty or as good as a father figure in the household. Flame on.
